newsitem.title: GERMANY: Software group SAP watched for sale slowdown signs.
newsitem.headline: Software group SAP watched for sale slowdown signs.

text.p: German software developer SAP AG will be watched closely even through the normally quiet end-year holiday period for any further indications of sales problems at the once buoyant company, analysts said.
SAP shares lost a quarter of their value in October after its third-quarter sales growth showed an unexpected slowdown.

"We are looking for any sign of what year-end numbers will come out in January," said Brian Wilkinson, who follows the company for HSBC James Capel in London. "SAP really has got to be as good as it's ever been to make its sales target."

SAP, whose R/3 software is used by businesses to keep track of accounting, purchasing, manufacturing and sales data, said in October it expected sales for the year to reach 3.5 billion marks ($2.3 billion) -- eight percent less than its previous forecast of 3.8 billion marks.
On Wednesday, SAP shares closed floor trading down 70 pfennigs at 204.5 marks. They were trading above 270 marks before SAP revised its sales estimates.
A disappointing fourth quarter could push the stock below the key support level of 200 marks, analysts said.

Also eagerly awaited is SAP's breakdown of sales, Wilkinson said. "The split of maintenance revenue versus new product fees will tell you how well R/3 is selling against competing products," he explained.
In September R/3 sales were 130 million marks below the level of June, a result which SAP officials have attributed to sluggish economies in Germany and a few other countries.
Yet sales of business software competitors PeopleSoft Inc. and Baan Co NV have soared without interruption, Wilkinson noted.

For the first nine months of 1996, SAP sales rose 33 percent to 2.4 billion marks ($1.55 billion). In the same period PeopleSoft saw total sales rise 95 percent to $296.5 million. Baan's nine-month revnues climbed 88 percent to $264 million, boosted by a doubling of product sales.
"A weak quarter for SAP coincided with good quarters for the competition," Wilkinson said. "The market is becoming tougher for them."

The eagerly awited fourth-quarter results will cap a trying year for SAP. Earlier this week co-founder Hans-Werner Hector quit his supervisory board post over differences with chief executive Dietmar Hopp.
Hector, who had been criticised by Hopp earlier this year for transferring some of his shares into a trust, said the supervisory board was ineffective against a management board dominated by Hopp.
Management boards of top executives handle the daily operations of German companies while outside supervisors oversee the development of the company and its management.

SAP also suffered a shock to its stock in April when U.S. consulting firm Forrester Research Inc said R/3 sales would peak in 1997 because SAP had not moved quickly enough to adapt it to the Internet.
The German firm plans to roll out its Internet version in the first quarter of 1997, later than many of its competitors.
